comment: The class was okay but a lot of it was through ALEKS. So, the professor did not really have any lectures and it was a lot of work homework wise. Definitely do not take if you are not prepared to do a lot of self-teaching and figuring out material on your own.

I aced all 3 tests, completely bombed the final, and ended with a B. He's a funny guy but you will have to teach everything to yourself. All homework is through ALEKs, including study guides. This is somewhat useful for repeating questions until you learn how to do it, but it is really easy to get burnt out or slack off by the end.

the content itself can be difficult if you don't ask for help. a lot of optional videos are posted on alecks and he answers emails. during lecture he reminds us when homework or exams are coming up but definitely work ahead as they pile up. does go off topic a bit but he's very kind. go to class!! if you miss one day you'll get behind.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Gives good feedback--Lots of homework

comment: Save your gpa and stay far away!!! He doesn't post any materials or supplemental videos, you basically teach yourself everything off of aleks (which also sucks). He doesn't post announcements or reminders either, so you are most likely going to miss multiple assignments because he never says what is due. I worked by butt off all semester for a c-

*MOST ACCURATE* Relies solely on ALEKS to teach ENTIRE course. You will truly learn more from YouTube than the professor you are paying for. A ton of HW with up to 14 topics a week and you have to get multiple questions right in a row to pass (very draining). 4 unit reviews, 4 tests and in-person final straight from ALEKS. I would NEVER take again!

You self teach yourself everything in Aleks. I know some professors that taught this class online before had small prerecorded lectures on the topics. Allen does not and there is nothing in D2L. Not a very caring or helpful person either. It took him a couple months to get his correct office hours link but isn't helpful in office hours anyway.

you will basically teach yourself the entire course if you have no knowledge or very little understanding to precalc. he rushes through powerpoints and never really goes into depth why things are the way they are. he really just relies on ALEKS for everything and gets his tests from there.wouldn't take him if you want a prof that is very detailed.

He is very hard. Does not review what you should know, no options for extra credit. He teaches from a PP and did not create it so lessons can be choppy. He did not finish PP lessons and was rushing through them bc classes are not long enough.

Do not take this prof. if you are new to pre-calc, you WILL be self teaching yourself. The only good thing is problems come directly from ALEKS. Unless you have prior pre-calc knowledge, avoid him at all cost; Lectures are all powerpoints, just save yourself $ and take online. If you do well w/ just ebook you'll pass, but no teaching here.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: It's pretty clear in his lectures that he is just very passionate about math and teaching it. The lectures weren't all that bad, about what you can expect plus some small jokes. I feel like he generally explained things pretty well. Most of his assignmetns are on ALEKS which the system isn't exactly great but not his fault. I recommend taking him.

Mr. Allen was a very clear-cut professor. He tells you what the grading criteria is going to be at the beginning of the semester, so you know what to expect. Trig is probably the hardest unit, and lectures get pretty monotone, so ALEKS is really helpful in learning the topics. Do the test review questions over and over again and you'll get an A.

His lectures can be slow and monotone, but if you can power through that he explains things well. The only issue is the tests. instead of breaking down problems into parts for partial credit opportunities, his tests are only 8-12 "show your work" questions. In my experience he was stingy with partial credit, so make sure you triple check everything
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: He's a great guy but teaches quickly. Your grade is basically what you make on the test. Homework is on ALEKS it really sucks. His test are hard he gave us test with 8 to 12 questions and the average was about 65 to a 75. Its a tough class. Also he post his blank notes so if you miss something and want to look back you are out of luck.
Great straight to the point professor. You have two responsibilities in the class, tests, and ALEKS. Simple course that should be a review from high school. Go to class! You won't pass if you don't.

Prof. Allen is amazing as long as you're okay with math lectures with a sprinkle of dad jokes with pop culture references. All the homework is given online through ALEKS, which makes it self-paced, but this doesn't mean you are alone if you are stuck on a topic. While the tests are short, the questions are essentially pulled from ALEKS.

I never considered myself very good at math, but I thought Mr. Allen gave you all the tools you needed to succeed in his class. He provided practice tests on ALEKS to review for tests, gave helpful tips in lecture, and allowed you to use a notecard for all tests. Just practice as much as you can, pay attention, and you can do well in this class.

Mr. Allen is a great instructor. He is very generous when it comes to homework grades. He offered to drop the lowest homework assignment grade. He was equally liberal when it came to giving out partial credit on the final exam. Overall, while this was a tough semester, it was primarily self-inflicted and had nothing to do with the instructor.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class--Online Savvy

comment: Prof. Allen's class was very hard work, and it's a HUGE grind to stay on top of things. That being said, he shows enough care in his lectures and is willing to work with you to a point if you're struggling like I was. If you're looking for a professor, he definitely isn't a bad choice, but you'll definitely have to work hard for a good grade.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria
